hint.details:
Calling (and then returning from) a function prevents many compiler optimizations (like vectorization), breaks control flow (which reduces pipeline performance) and executes extra instructions to save/restore the registers used inside it, which is very expensive (dozens of cycles). Consider to inline small functions.
  • rand@plt: 1 occurrences<>
hint.title: CALL instructions

hint.details:
These instructions generate more than one micro-operation and only one of them can be decoded during a cycle and the extra micro-operations increase pressure on execution units.
  • VCVTSI2SD: 1 occurrences<>
hint.title: Complex instructions

hint.workaround: Avoid mixing data with different types. In particular, check if the type of constants is the same as array elements.
hint.title: Conversion instructions
Type of elements and instruction set

hint.txt: Arithmetic intensity is 0.06 FP operations per loaded or stored byte.

hint.workaround: Unroll your loop if trip count is significantly higher than target unroll factor. This can be done manually. Or with the unroll (resp. unroll_and_jam) directive on top of the inner (resp. surrounding) loop. You can enforce an unroll factor: #pragma unroll_and_jam N, unroll_and_jam(N), unroll N or unroll(N)

expert.title: Cycles and memory resources usage
expert.txt:
Assuming all data fit into the L1 cache, each iteration of the binary loop takes 4.50 cycles. At this rate:
  • 1% of peak load performance is reached (1.78 out of 96.00 bytes loaded per cycle (GB/s @ 1GHz))
  • 2% of peak store performance is reached (1.78 out of 64.00 bytes stored per cycle (GB/s @ 1GHz))

header:
Warnings:
Detected a function call instruction: ignoring called function instructions.
Rerun with --follow-calls=append to include them to analysis  or with --follow-calls=inline to simulate inlining.
0% of peak computational performance is used (0.22 out of 24.00 FLOP per cycle (GFLOPS @ 1GHz))

gain.workaround:
• Try another compiler or update/tune your current one:
    • recompile with O2 or higher to enable loop vectorization and with ffast-math (included in Ofast) to extend vectorization to FP reductions.
  • Remove inter-iterations dependences from your loop and make it unit-stride:
    • If your arrays have 2 or more dimensions, check whether elements are accessed contiguously and, otherwise, try to permute loops accordingly: C storage order is row-major: for(i) for(j) a[j][i] = b[j][i]; (slow, non stride 1) => for(i) for(j) a[i][j] = b[i][j]; (fast, stride 1)<>
    • If your loop streams arrays of structures (AoS), try to use structures of arrays instead (SoA): for(i) a[i].x = b[i].x; (slow, non stride 1) => for(i) a.x[i] = b.x[i]; (fast, stride 1)
gain.details:
All SSE/AVX instructions are used in scalar version (process only one data element in vector registers).
Since your execution units are vector units, only a vectorized loop can use their full power.
gain.title: Vectorization
gain.txt:
Your loop is not vectorized.
Only 20% of vector register length is used (average across all SSE/AVX instructions).
By vectorizing your loop, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 4.50 to 1.12 cycles (4.00x speedup).

gain.workaround:
• Reduce the number of division or square root instructions:
    • If denominator is constant over iterations, use reciprocal (replace x/y with x*(1/y)). Check precision impact. This will be done by your compiler with ffast-math or Ofast
  • Check whether you really need double precision. If not, switch to single precision to speedup execution
gain.title: Execution units bottlenecks
gain.txt:
Performance is limited by execution of divide and square root operations (the divide/square root unit is a bottleneck).

By removing all these bottlenecks, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 4.50 to 2.00 cycles (2.25x speedup).

potential.title: Expensive FP math instructions/calls
potential.txt:
Detected performance impact from expensive FP math instructions/calls.
By removing/reexpressing them, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 4.50 to 2.00 cycles (2.25x speedup).
